elements.content: The detection of nitro compounds and removal of organic dyes remain urgent issues because they are poisonous to humans. Taking advantage of metal–organic framework (MOF) materials, we demonstrate herein an indium–organic framework (InOF) exhibiting sensitive fluorescence sensing of nitro compounds, prominent dye capture, and excellent photodegradation of dyes. By using 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-p-aminobenzoate (TATAB), an amino-functionalized BTB-like linker, the 3D SNNU-110 structure ({[In3OCl­(H2O)2(TATAB)2]} n ) is formed. SNNU-110 shows a 3,6-connected 3,6T22 topology with TATAB and [In3O­(CO2)6] tricapped trigonal-prismatic clusters as 3- and 6-connected nodes. Thanks to the fluorescence properties and amine recognition sites of TATAB, SNNU-110 exhibits excellent performance of fluorescence quenching for six electron-deficient nitroaromatics. The intercrossing 1D channels in SNNU-110 formed from the a- and b-axis directions with dimensions of about 18 Å × 11 Å can capture diverse cationic, anionic, or neutral dyes effectively. What is more, the existence of an inorganic [In3O] cluster enable SNNU-110 to be a good photocatalyst. Upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp, SNNU-110 shows outstanding photocatalytic activity toward rhodamine B (RhB) and methylene blue (MB), and there was almost no degradation. The catalytic activity can retain about 94.6% (RhB) and 93.1% (MB), respectively. Overall, SNNU-110 fully demonstrates the power of multicomponent MOFs, which provide a feasible route for the design of functional materials toward to pollutant identification and removal applications.

elements.content: A multifunctional indium−organic framework designed by a topological transformation strategy exhibits good fluorescent sensing of nitro compounds, prominent physical capture, and remarkable photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes.
elements.clean_text: A multifunctional indium-organic framework designed by a topological transformation strategy exhibits good fluorescent sensing of nitro compounds, prominent physical capture, and remarkable photocatalytic degradation of organic dyes.

elements.content: Over the past decades, more and more attention has been paid to the problem of chemical pollutants. Among a variety of pollutants, organic dyes and nitro compounds are of particular concern because they are poisonous and harmful. The detection of nitro compounds and removal of organic dye molecules have remained urgent issues in the past several years. Among the various detection methods for nitro compounds, fluorescent sensors that possess the advantage of high sensitivity, fast response, and flexible and convenient operation have attracted extensive research in the last few decades. On the other hand, physical adsorption and photodegradation technologies are regarded as the most promising routes for removal of the dyes, because they are environmentally and ecologically friendly.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, more and more attention has been paid to the problem of chemical pollutants. Among a variety of pollutants, organic dyes and nitro compounds are of particular concern because they are poisonous and harmful. The detection of nitro compounds and removal of organic dye molecules have remained urgent issues in the past several years. Among the various detection methods for nitro compounds, fluorescent sensors that possess the advantage of high sensitivity, fast response, and flexible and convenient operation have attracted extensive research in the last few decades. On the other hand, physical adsorption and photodegradation technologies are regarded as the most promising routes for removal of the dyes, because they are environmentally and ecologically friendly.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), assembled from metal/metal nodes and organic linkers, have shown great strength in the past few decades. Given their inherent characteristics of high specific surface area, designable channel size, and controllable pore environment, MOFs have become important candidates for the detection and removal of chemical pollutants. On this basis, MOFs can achieve physical and/or selective adsorption of dye through porosity, host–guest interactions, and ionic properties. In addition, the development of semiconducting MOF materials as active photocatalysts has broad application prospects in the degradation of organic pollutants. It is noted that partial MOFs have been proven to be capable of adsorption or photodegradation of organic dye pollutants, but most of them are still of low efficiency and practicality. In recent years, the use of MOF materials as fluorescence identification and detection probes for nitroaromatic molecules has been reported. However, many reported MOF sensors have drawbacks such as low sensitivity, a narrow linear detection range, and so on. So, the development of new MOF materials for organic dye decontamination and nitroaromatic fluorescent sensing is still a crucial and glamorous task.

In addition, the development of semiconducting MOF materials as active photocatalysts has broad application prospects in the degradation of organic pollutants. It is noted that partial MOFs have been proven to be capable of adsorption or photodegradation of organic dye pollutants, but most of them are still of low efficiency and practicality. In recent years, the use of MOF materials as fluorescence identification and detection probes for nitroaromatic molecules has been reported. However, many reported MOF sensors have drawbacks such as low sensitivity, a narrow linear detection range, and so on. So, the development of new MOF materials for organic dye decontamination and nitroaromatic fluorescent sensing is still a crucial and glamorous task.

elements.content: As an extension of our continuous work on fluorescent sensors and dye removal MOFs, we now focus on the integration of the fluorescent sensing performance and dye capture and photodegradation functions into one MOF. It is speculated that multifunctional MOF materials have many more potential applications because the practical pollutant system is usually complex. As is known, these types of multifunctional MOFs have rarely been reported so far.

elements.content: Keeping the above consideration in mind, a typical trinuclear cluster, [In3O­(CO2)6] with predicable linking and high stability, has attracted our attention in the development of multifunctional indium–organic frameworks (InOFs). Similar to In2O3, the semiconducting performance of InOF materials makes them potential photocatalysts toward organic pollutant degradation. Inspired by InPF-110, a high-performance MOF catalyst based on the 2-[bis­(2-hydroxyethyl)­amino]-2-(hydroxymethyl)­propane-1,3-diol (BTB) ligand and [In3O­(CO2)6] cluster, 4,4′,4″-s-triazine-1,3,5-triyltri-p-aminobenzoate (TATAB), is selected in this work. As a result, the extended and amino-functionalized tritopic TATAB linker formed {[In3OCl­(H2O)2(TATAB)2]} n (SNNU-110; ). Each TATAB linker connects six [In3O­(CO2)6] motifs to give a 3D 3,6-connected framework with 3,6T22 topology, which is clearly different from the 3,6T60 topology of InPF-110. The intercrossing 1D channels enable SNNU-110 to capture diverse cationic, anionic, or neutral dyes effectively. Also, benefiting from the unique fluorescence performance of the TATAB ligands, SNNU-110 can quantitively sense nitro compounds with large quenching coefficients. What is more, SNNU-110 shows a distinguished photodegradation performance for methylene blue (MB) and rhodamine B (RhB). Undoubtedly, the InOF demonstrated herein provides a feasible route for the design of environmentally related multifunctional materials.

elements.content: In­(NO3)3·xH2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (47 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylacetamide (DMA; 1 mL), and 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (1 mL) were mixed together in a vial, ultrasonicated for 30 min, and then heated at 90 °C for 3 days. The colorless polyhedral crystals (Figure S1) were collected and washed with DMA. The yield was around 75% based on metal salt.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of {[In3OCl(H2O)2(TATAB)2]} n  (SNNU-110)

In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (47 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylacetamide (DMA; 1 mL), and 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (1 mL) were mixed together in a vial, ultrasonicated for 30 min, and then heated at 90 °C for 3 days. The colorless polyhedral crystals (Figure S1) were collected and washed with DMA. The yield was around 75% based on metal salt.

X-ray Structure Determinations

Single-crystal structure refinement was performed on a Bruker Smart APEX II CCD area with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structure was solved directly and then refined with the software SHELXTL. The details of the crystal data are summarized in .

The influence of the solvent on the fluorescence properties of SNNU-110 was first investigated by introducing a MOF fine powder into 50 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), 1,4-dioxane (1,4-DO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 1-butyl alcohol, respectively. After sonication treatment and aging for 3 days, the fluorescence spectra were measured. For further detection of the sensing properties, desired amounts of nitro compounds were added into the SNNU-110 emulsion in DMSO (7 mg MOF in 100 mL of DMSO), and the photoluminescence (PL) spectra were investigated after vigorous shaking. The stability of SNNU-110 during fluorescence sensing experiments was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Sensing Experiments

The influence of the solvent on the fluorescence properties of SNNU-110 was first investigated by introducing a MOF fine powder into 50 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), 1,4-dioxane (1,4-DO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), and 1-butyl alcohol, respectively. After sonication treatment and aging for 3 days, the fluorescence spectra were measured. For further detection of the sensing properties, desired amounts of nitro compounds were added into the SNNU-110 emulsion in DMSO (7 mg MOF in 100 mL of DMSO), and the photoluminescence (PL) spectra were investigated after vigorous shaking. The stability of SNNU-110 during fluorescence sensing experiments was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

elements.content: Aqueous solutions of methyl orange (MO), RhB, ponceau S (PS), MB, and sunset yellow (SY) were prepared by dissolving solid dye in distilled water. As-synthesized SNNU-110 material (20 mg) was immersed in the dye aqueous solution. In order to correct the dye concentrations, the typical absorbance at a maximum absorption wavelength was monitored by a UV–vis spectrophotometer. The adsorption rate constant and maximum adsorption capability were calculated by using the pseudo-second-order reaction kinetics and Langmuir adsorption isotherms, respectively. When the adsorption experiments were tested at different temperatures, the thermodynamic parameters of dye adsorption were obtained.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Adsorption Measurements

Aqueous solutions of methyl orange (MO), RhB, ponceau S (PS), MB, and sunset yellow (SY) were prepared by dissolving solid dye in distilled water. As-synthesized SNNU-110 material (20 mg) was immersed in the dye aqueous solution. In order to correct the dye concentrations, the typical absorbance at a maximum absorption wavelength was monitored by a UV-vis spectrophotometer. The adsorption rate constant and maximum adsorption capability were calculated by using the pseudo-second-order reaction kinetics and Langmuir adsorption isotherms, respectively. When the adsorption experiments were tested at different temperatures, the thermodynamic parameters of dye adsorption were obtained.

elements.content: The photodegradation experiments were performed via the addition of SNNU-110 or In2O3 to aqueous solutions of MB and RhB at ambient temperature. The details of experiments were as follows: 15 mg of the photocatalyst SNNU-110 or In2O3 was added to 10 mL of a MB or RhB solution and then magnetized overnight in the dark, with the aim of balancing the adsorption and desorption between the dye and MOFs. In order to maintain a photocatalyst suspension, air was continuously pumped into the bottom, and then the photodegradation reactions were carried out using a 300 W xenon lamp. Further, a supernatant liquid was extracted regularly, by monitoring the absorbance of MB and RhB, and the concentration of dye was determined. PXRD was performed to confirm the stability of SNNU-110 during photocatalytic degradation measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalytic Degradation Measurements

The photodegradation experiments were performed via the addition of SNNU-110 or In2O3 to aqueous solutions of MB and RhB at ambient temperature. The details of experiments were as follows: 15 mg of the photocatalyst SNNU-110 or In2O3 was added to 10 mL of a MB or RhB solution and then magnetized overnight in the dark, with the aim of balancing the adsorption and desorption between the dye and MOFs. In order to maintain a photocatalyst suspension, air was continuously pumped into the bottom, and then the photodegradation reactions were carried out using a 300 W xenon lamp. Further, a supernatant liquid was extracted regularly, by monitoring the absorbance of MB and RhB, and the concentration of dye was determined. PXRD was performed to confirm the stability of SNNU-110 during photocatalytic degradation measurements.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that SNNU-110 crystallizes in the chiral tetragonal space group P41212 (). This is supported by the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra (Figure S2). Two types of crystallographically independent In, one TATAB ligand, one terminally coordinated H2O, and one Cl ion exist in the asymmetric unit of SNNU-110 (Figure S3). Both In centers are of distorted octahedral geometry. In1 is coordinated by one μ3-O atom, four carboxylate O atoms, and one Cl atom. In2 is coordinated by one μ3-O atom, four carboxylate O atoms, and one H2O molecule. The central O atom links three In cations to form a planar [In3O] motif with In–O and In–Cl bonds of 2.021(4), 2.057(2), and 2.4001(14) Å (Table S1). Six bridging carboxylate groups help to generate a typical [In3O­(CO2)6]+ tricapped trigonal-prismatic cluster (a), which is charge-balanced by a Cl anion. Each TATAB ligand connects three trinuclear clusters through three carboxylate groups, and six TATAB ligands lie symmetrically up and down around each trinuclear cluster. Such repeating link modes lead to the 3D framework of SNNU-110 (b).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure and Characterizations

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that SNNU-110 crystallizes in the chiral tetragonal space group P41212 (). This is supported by the solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra (Figure S2). Two types of crystallographically independent In, one TATAB ligand, one terminally coordinated H2O, and one Cl ion exist in the asymmetric unit of SNNU-110 (Figure S3). Both In centers are of distorted octahedral geometry. In1 is coordinated by one μ3-O atom, four carboxylate O atoms, and one Cl atom. In2 is coordinated by one μ3-O atom, four carboxylate O atoms, and one H2O molecule. The central O atom links three In cations to form a planar [In3O] motif with In-O and In-Cl bonds of 2.021(4), 2.057(2), and 2.4001(14) Å (Table S1). Six bridging carboxylate groups help to generate a typical [In3O(CO2)6]+ tricapped trigonal-prismatic cluster (a), which is charge-balanced by a Cl anion. Each TATAB ligand connects three trinuclear clusters through three carboxylate groups, and six TATAB ligands lie symmetrically up and down around each trinuclear cluster. Such repeating link modes lead to the 3D framework of SNNU-110 (b).

elements.content: Crystal structures of SNNU-110: (a) linkage between the [In3O­(COO)6] cluster and TATAB ligand; (b) 3D porous architecture; (c) octahedral cage; (d) tetrahedral cage; (e) 3,6-connected topological net; (f) tiles.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structures of SNNU-110: (a) linkage between the [In3O(COO)6] cluster and TATAB ligand; (b) 3D porous architecture; (c) octahedral cage; (d) tetrahedral cage; (e) 3,6-connected topological net; (f) tiles.

elements.content: It is noted that large intercrossing 1D channels are observed along the a- and b-axis directions in the structure, which have dimensions of about 18 Å × 11 Å (Figure S3). A detailed analysis of the structure reveals that two types of polyhedral cages exist. Six [In3O­(CO2)6] clusters serving as vertices link eight TATAB ligands to form the octahedral cage (c). The tetrahedral cage is generated by four [In3O­(CO2)6] clusters and four TATAB ligands (d). Two types of cages link each other via a face-sharing fashion. Overall, SNNU-110 exhibits a 3,6-connected 3D framework with [In3O­(CO2)6] prismatic clusters as 6-connected nodes and TATAB ligands as 3-connected nodes (e). The whole net exhibits a 3,6T22 topology with a point symbol of {611.84}­{63}2. To the best of our knowledge, only two MOFs with tropic carboxylate ligands and a single [In3O­(CO2)6] building block have been reported. Compared to TATAB, the shorter BTB linker leads to InPF-110 with a 3,6T60 topology, but the longer urea-containing linker generates URMOF-4, possessing a special flu-3,6-P3121 topology. This clearly demonstrates the diversity of [In3O­(CO2)6] building blocks for the construction of MOFs.

elements.content: PXRD confirmed the crystallinity and purity for SNNU-110 (Figure S4). To examine the stability of SNNU-110, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies were carried out under a N2 atmosphere in the temperature range 25–900 °C. The coordinated H2O molecules and Cl atoms were lost from 25 to 105 °C (found, 10.23%; calcd, 10.67%). After that, the TATAB ligands started to decompose. The final product was In2O3 (found, 26.56%; calcd, 28.03%; Figure S5). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of SNNU-110 show strong absorption peaks in the range of 3000–3500 cm–1, which is attributed to the characteristic peaks of O–H, C–H, and N–H vibrations. Peaks at 1614 and 1387 cm–1 belong to stretching vibrations of the carboxyl moiety. The peak at 771 cm–1 could be considered to belong to the out-of-plane bending vibration of C–H on benzene (Figure S6). Considering that SNNU-110 is a noncentrosymmetric framework, the nonlinear-optical property was also investigated. Kurtz and Perry proposed this rule. The variation trend of the SHG signal with the particle size is shown in Figure S7. By using pure powder samples to test the SHG effect of SNNU-110, it was found that SNNU-110 has matching characteristics when the wavelength was 1064 nm, and its intensity was 3 times that of KDP in the same conditions. Moreover, the N2 adsorption at 77 K of SNNU-110 showed a typical mesopore, and the uptake amount at 1 atm was 147 cm3 g–1. The calculated pore size well-matched that of the single-crystal structure (Figure S8).

elements.content: MOF materials, constructed by d10 metal ions or π–π-stacking organic ligands, are considered to be potential candidates for luminescent performance. The solid state for SNNU-110 showed apparent fluorescence with an intense emission band at 351 nm (λex = 276 nm), which may be caused by luminescence of the H3TATAB organic ligand. At room temperature (λex = 276 nm), transient fluorescence experiments of SNNU-110 were also tested, and the results show that it belongs to a monoexponential curve and the lifetime was 1.76 ns, indicating that SNNU-110 with a tricapped trigonal-prismatic cluster has good fluorescence properties. PL of SNNU-110 was then studied in different organic solvents to evaluate its sensing performance. MOF samples (10 mg) were ground into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents. After 2 h, the MOF sample (10 mg) was ground and then added into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents such as THF, DMSO, 1,4-DO, and butyl alcohol. After ultrasonic treatment for 2 h, the mixture was aged for 3 days to form a stable suspension, and then fluorescence detection was carried out. As shown in b and S9a, the PL intensity and peak position were apparently dependent on the solvent, which indicates that the π-conjugated TATAB emission can be tuned by the weak interactions between ligands and solvents such as hydrogen bonds and so on. SNNU-110 has the strongest emissions in DMSO, and the maximum emission is at 340 nm, which is in good agreement with the value of the solid sample. In contrast, SNNU-110 in nitrobenzene (NB) displayed complete PL quenching. These results encourage us to further evaluate the fluorescence detection of NB by the SNNU-110 sensor in DMSO.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescent Sensing of Nitro Compounds

MOF materials, constructed by d10 metal ions or π-π-stacking organic ligands, are considered to be potential candidates for luminescent performance. The solid state for SNNU-110 showed apparent fluorescence with an intense emission band at 351 nm (λex = 276 nm), which may be caused by luminescence of the H3TATAB organic ligand. At room temperature (λex = 276 nm), transient fluorescence experiments of SNNU-110 were also tested, and the results show that it belongs to a monoexponential curve and the lifetime was 1.76 ns, indicating that SNNU-110 with a tricapped trigonal-prismatic cluster has good fluorescence properties. PL of SNNU-110 was then studied in different organic solvents to evaluate its sensing performance. MOF samples (10 mg) were ground into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents. After 2 h, the MOF sample (10 mg) was ground and then added into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents such as THF, DMSO, 1,4-DO, and butyl alcohol. After ultrasonic treatment for 2 h, the mixture was aged for 3 days to form a stable suspension, and then fluorescence detection was carried out. As shown in b and S9a, the PL intensity and peak position were apparently dependent on the solvent, which indicates that the π-conjugated TATAB emission can be tuned by the weak interactions between ligands and solvents such as hydrogen bonds and so on. SNNU-110 has the strongest emissions in DMSO, and the maximum emission is at 340 nm, which is in good agreement with the value of the solid sample. In contrast, SNNU-110 in nitrobenzene (NB) displayed complete PL quenching. These results encourage us to further evaluate the fluorescence detection of NB by the SNNU-110 sensor in DMSO.

elements.content: In order to detect its PL response more carefully, a series of SNNU-110 suspension solutions of NB in DMSO with increasing concentration were characterized. As shown in c, the fluorescence intensities decreased significantly with increases of NB. The fluorescence quenching effect may be derived from the interaction between the skeleton and small organic molecules. Upon excitation, energy transfer from the amino group of TATAB to a NB molecule occurred and led to fluorescence quenching. As a comparison, the fluorescence spectra of the free H3TATAB ligand in a DMSO solution with the addition of different amounts of NB showed neglectable changes. So, the good fluorescence sensing performance of SNNU-110 should be attributed to a synergistic effect of TATAB and the MOF framework. Six different nitro compounds were used to detect the luminescence of SNNU-110, including nitromethane, 1,2-dinitrobenzene (1,2-DNB), picric acid (PA), 1,3-dinitrobenzene (1,3-DNB), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (DNT), and 2,4,6-trinitrophenol (TNT). The luminescence changes can be measured at 274 nm by adding analytes (c–e and S9), which are almost quenchable except for nitromethane (Figure S9).
elements.clean_text: In order to detect its PL response more carefully, a series of SNNU-110 suspension solutions of NB in DMSO with increasing concentration were characterized. As shown in c, the fluorescence intensities decreased significantly with increases of NB. elements.content: It is worth noting that, except for the slightly unstable emission stage, there is a significant linear relationship between the fluorescence quenching and the increase of the NB concentration for the SNNU-110 sensor (f and S10 and S11). The fluorescence intensity was closely related to the concentration of nitro compounds, which can be analyzed by the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 1 + K SV[nitro compounds], where I 0 is the fluorescence intensity of pure DMSO and the concentrations of the nitro compounds range from 0 to 200 ppm. At low concentrations, the calibration curve has a good linear relationship with R 2, which is greater than 0.98. Thanks to the π-conjugated character and amino recognition sites of TATAB, SNNU-110 can quantitively sense nitroaromatic compounds with a large quenching coefficient and K SV values of 1.5 × 104 M–1 for NB, 1.2 × 104 M–1 for 1,3-DNB, 2.6 × 104 M–1 for 1,2-DNB, 2.2 × 104 M–1 for DNT, 3.3 × 104 M–1 for TNT, and 2.3 × 104 M–1 for PA. Notably, these K SV values of SNNU-110 for PA, NB, and TNT were higher than or comparable with those of other reported MOF sensors (Tables S2–S4).

elements.content: Furthermore, on the basis of DL = 3σ/slope (Figure S12), SNNU-110 has good sensitivity to nitroaromatic compounds, and the detection limits are as low as 1.93 × 10–5 M (2.38 ppm) for NB, 2.01 × 10–5 M (3.39 ppm) for 1,3-DNB, 1.16 × 10–5 M (1.95 ppm) for 1,2-DNB, 1.09 × 10–5 M (1.99 ppm) for DNT, 9.1 × 10–6 M (1.42 ppm) for TNT, and 8.47 × 10–6 M (1.94 ppm) for PA. Overall, the amino groups are important in the detection of nitroaromatic explosives. Also, the fluorescent quenching of SNNU-110 is probably because the electrons from the amino group are transferred to the nitro compound.

elements.content: To explore the mechanism of sensing of NB, the transient fluorescence quenching experiments were conducted by monitoring the fluorescence attenuation of SNNU-110 before and after the addition of NB at different concentrations. The decay curve shows only a small change in the values of the lifetime, indicating that the quenching process is essentially static (Figure S10). The repeatability of the SNNU-110 sensor is verified by cyclic experiments (Figure S9). In order to test the recyclability of SNNU-110 for NB detection, after each fluorescence test, the materials were recovered by centrifugation and washed with DMSO several times. The recovered SNNU-110 has no obvious change in its luminescence intensity within seven sensory recovery cycles, indicating that SNNU-110 has good recyclability.

elements.content: According to the PLATON calculation, it was estimated that the solvent-accessible free volume of SNNU-110 is 79.7%, which enables SNNU-110 to be used as a potential dye adsorption material. Therefore, the interaction between the organic dye and SNNU-110 was further studied comprehensively. For the larger pores of SNNU-110, the linear and 1– charged dye MO was first selected to be studied. In general, fresh SNNU-110 samples (20 mg) were added to a MO aqueous solution (30 mg L–1, 30 mL) and left in the dark at room temperature. The yellow solution faded to colorless after 24 h (b). The adsorption ability of SNNU-110 on dyes in an aqueous solution was quantitatively evaluated by UV–vis spectrophotometry. The results showed that the concentration of MO in water decreased significantly with the extension of time. After 12 h, as for MO (the initial concentration is 30 mg L–1), the adsorption amount was 23.6 mg g–1 (a) for SNNU-110.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Adsorption of Organic Dyes

According to the PLATON calculation, it was estimated that the solvent-accessible free volume of SNNU-110 is 79.7%, which enables SNNU-110 to be used as a potential dye adsorption material. Therefore, the interaction between the organic dye and SNNU-110 was further studied comprehensively. For the larger pores of SNNU-110, the linear and 1- charged dye MO was first selected to be studied. In general, fresh SNNU-110 samples (20 mg) were added to a MO aqueous solution (30 mg L-1, 30 mL) and left in the dark at room temperature. The yellow solution faded to colorless after 24 h (b). The adsorption ability of SNNU-110 on dyes in an aqueous solution was quantitatively evaluated by UV-vis spectrophotometry. The results showed that the concentration of MO in water decreased significantly with the extension of time. After 12 h, as for MO (the initial concentration is 30 mg L-1), the adsorption amount was 23.6 mg g-1 (a) for SNNU-110.

elements.content: In addition, considering that MO and MB are similar in size but different in charge, we chose them for comparison. The result shows that a neutral SNNU-110 MOF can uptake not only negatively charged dye MO but also positively charged dye MB (f). A further comparison of the experiments showed that the maximum absorption band intensity of MO at 463 nm dramatically dropped within 1 h after the addition of SNNU-110, while there was negligible absorbance change for MB under the same conditions. Because the molecular diameters of MO and MB are similar, the rapid capture of MO may be attributed to the strong hydrogen bond between the −SO3– groups from MO and the amino group from the TATAB linkers.

elements.content: Furthermore, SNNU-110 was used to adsorb larger cationic dye RhB. After 12 h, as shown in b, the adsorption amount was 29.7 mg g–1 (the initial concentration of RhB was 30 mg L–1). In addition, a larger anionic dye (SY) may be attributed to their similar structural nature. In addition, the adsorption of PS was also examined. Overall, a neutral SNNU-110 MOF material captured all of the selected organic dyes but exhibited different adsorption rates. Within 24 h, SNNU-110 adsorbed 90.2% of MB, 85.4% of MO, 90.0% of SY, 94.8% of RhB, and 77.4% of PS.

It is noted that indium oxide is a well-researched photocatalyst. Together with its highly porous structure, it is speculated that SNNU-110 should have a promising photocatalysis performance toward organic pollutant degradation. The optical band gap (E g) of the photocatalyst is an important index to evaluate the efficiency of the photocatalysis process. We used the Kubelka–Munk equation to convert the recorded SNNU-110 and In2O3 solid-state diffuse-reflectance spectra, and the results showed that the E g values are 3.53 eV for SNNU-110 and 3.08 eV for In2O3 (Figure S13), suggesting that SNNU-110 is a potential semiconductor material that could be used as a photocatalyst.
elements.clean_text:
Photodegradation of Organic Dyes

It is noted that indium oxide is a well-researched photocatalyst. Together with its highly porous structure, it is speculated that SNNU-110 should have a promising photocatalysis performance toward organic pollutant degradation. The optical band gap (E g) of the photocatalyst is an important index to evaluate the efficiency of the photocatalysis process. We used the Kubelka-Munk equation to convert the recorded SNNU-110 and In2O3 solid-state diffuse-reflectance spectra, and the results showed that the E g values are 3.53 eV for SNNU-110 and 3.08 eV for In2O3 (Figure S13), suggesting that SNNU-110 is a potential semiconductor material that could be used as a photocatalyst.

elements.content: The photodegradation of MB and RhB aqueous solutions at ambient temperature was further carried out with SNNU-110 and In2O3 as photocatalysts. When adsorption–desorption of the dye and photocatalyst was at equilibrium in the dark, the photodegradation reaction was carried out under irradiation of a 300 W xenon lamp. The typical absorption bands of RhB and MB nearly vanish after 70 and 190 min after the addition of SNNU-110 as the photocatalyst, and the corresponding degradation efficiencies are 94.6% and 93.1%, respectively ( and S14). When In2O3 was added as the photocatalyst, the typical absorption bands of RhB and MB changed very little after 70 and 190 min (Figure S14). The control irradiation experiments without the MOF photocatalyst showed that the absorption intensities of RhB and MB were basically constant (Figure S14). Together with the above physical adsorption of RhB and MB, the SNNU-110 material is a promising candidate for the practical removal of organic dye pollutants.

The typical absorption bands of RhB and MB nearly vanish after 70 and 190 min after the addition of SNNU-110 as the photocatalyst, and the corresponding degradation efficiencies are 94.6% and 93.1%, respectively ( and S14). When In2O3 was added as the photocatalyst, the typical absorption bands of RhB and MB changed very little after 70 and 190 min (Figure S14). The control irradiation experiments without the MOF photocatalyst showed that the absorption intensities of RhB and MB were basically constant (Figure S14). Together with the above physical adsorption of RhB and MB, the SNNU-110 material is a promising candidate for the practical removal of organic dye pollutants.

elements.content: In summary, a multifunctional 3D InOF, namely, SNNU-110, has been designed through topological transformation by the evolution of tritopic carboxylate linkers. SNNU-110 exhibits a neutral [In3O­(CO2)6]-based framework with a channel-type interior space filled by triazine rings and amine groups. The fluorescent TATAB linker with amine recognition sites makes SNNU-110 a good nitroaromatic compound sensor. The intercrossing 1D channels help SNNU-110 to effectively capture diverse cationic, anionic, or neutral dyes. The [In3O] inorganic cluster provides SNNU-110 with excellent photodegradation activity toward RhB and MB. More importantly, the SNNU-110 MOF showed high stability during all fluorescent sensing, dye adsorption, and photocatalytic degradation experiments. Anyway, this work fully demonstrates the power of MOFs as multifunctional materials toward to pollutant identification and removal applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, a multifunctional 3D InOF, namely, SNNU-110, has been designed through topological transformation by the evolution of tritopic carboxylate linkers. SNNU-110 exhibits a neutral [In3O(CO2)6]-based framework with a channel-type interior space filled by triazine rings and amine groups. The fluorescent TATAB linker with amine recognition sites makes SNNU-110 a good nitroaromatic compound sensor. The intercrossing 1D channels help SNNU-110 to effectively capture diverse cationic, anionic, or neutral dyes. The [In3O] inorganic cluster provides SNNU-110 with excellent photodegradation activity toward RhB and MB. More importantly, the SNNU-110 MOF showed high stability during all fluorescent sensing, dye adsorption, and photocatalytic degradation experiments. Anyway, this work fully demonstrates the power of MOFs as multifunctional materials toward to pollutant identification and removal applications.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of {[In3OCl(H2O)2(TATAB)2]} n  (SNNU-110)

In(NO3)3⋅xH2O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), H3TATAB (47 mg, 0.1 mmol), dimethylacetamide (DMA; 1 mL), and 1,3-dimethyl-2-imidazolidinone (1 mL) were mixed together in a vial, ultrasonicated for 30 min, and then heated at 90 °C for 3 days. The colorless polyhedral crystals (Figure S1) were collected and washed with DMA. The yield was around 75% based on metal salt.

cln_elements.content:
PXRD confirmed the crystallinity and purity for SNNU-110 (Figure S4). To examine the stability of SNNU-110, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) studies were carried out under a N2 atmosphere in the temperature range 25–900 °C. The coordinated H2O molecules and Cl atoms were lost from 25 to 105 °C (found, 10.23%; calcd, 10.67%). After that, the TATAB ligands started to decompose. The final product was In2O3 (found, 26.56%; calcd, 28.03%; Figure S5). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of SNNU-110 show strong absorption peaks in the range of 3000–3500 cm–1, which is attributed to the characteristic peaks of O–H, C–H, and N–H vibrations. Peaks at 1614 and 1387 cm–1 belong to stretching vibrations of the carboxyl moiety. The peak at 771 cm–1 could be considered to belong to the out-of-plane bending vibration of C–H on benzene (Figure S6). Considering that SNNU-110 is a noncentrosymmetric framework, the nonlinear-optical property was also investigated. Kurtz and Perry proposed this rule. The variation trend of the SHG signal with the particle size is shown in Figure S7. By using pure powder samples to test the SHG effect of SNNU-110, it was found that SNNU-110 has matching characteristics when the wavelength was 1064 nm, and its intensity was 3 times that of KDP in the same conditions. Moreover, the N2 adsorption at 77 K of SNNU-110 showed a typical mesopore, and the uptake amount at 1 atm was 147 cm3 g–1. The calculated pore size well-matched that of the single-crystal structure (Figure S8).

Fluorescent Sensing of Nitro Compounds

MOF materials, constructed by d10 metal ions or π–π-stacking organic ligands, are considered to be potential candidates for luminescent performance. The solid state for SNNU-110 showed apparent fluorescence with an intense emission band at 351 nm (λex = 276 nm), which may be caused by luminescence of the H3TATAB organic ligand. At room temperature (λex = 276 nm), transient fluorescence experiments of SNNU-110 were also tested, and the results show that it belongs to a monoexponential curve and the lifetime was 1.76 ns, indicating that SNNU-110 with a tricapped trigonal-prismatic cluster has good fluorescence properties. PL of SNNU-110 was then studied in different organic solvents to evaluate its sensing performance. MOF samples (10 mg) were ground into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents. After 2 h, the MOF sample (10 mg) was ground and then added into 2.5 mL of different organic solvents such as THF, DMSO, 1,4-DO, and butyl alcohol. After ultrasonic treatment for 2 h, the mixture was aged for 3 days to form a stable suspension, and then fluorescence detection was carried out. As shown in b and S9a, the PL intensity and peak position were apparently dependent on the solvent, which indicates that the π-conjugated TATAB emission can be tuned by the weak interactions between ligands and solvents such as hydrogen bonds and so on. SNNU-110 has the strongest emissions in DMSO, and the maximum emission is at 340 nm, which is in good agreement with the value of the solid sample. In contrast, SNNU-110 in nitrobenzene (NB) displayed complete PL quenching. These results encourage us to further evaluate the fluorescence detection of NB by the SNNU-110 sensor in DMSO.

Furthermore, SNNU-110 was used to adsorb larger cationic dye RhB. After 12 h, as shown in b, the adsorption amount was 29.7 mg g–1 (the initial concentration of RhB was 30 mg L–1). In addition, a larger anionic dye (SY) may be attributed to their similar structural nature. In addition, the adsorption of PS was also examined. Overall, a neutral SNNU-110 MOF material captured all of the selected organic dyes but exhibited different adsorption rates. Within 24 h, SNNU-110 adsorbed 90.2% of MB, 85.4% of MO, 90.0% of SY, 94.8% of RhB, and 77.4% of PS.
